title: How to Make Garlic Shrimp

steps.headline: Peel and devein 1 pound (0.45 kg) of large, raw shrimp.
steps.description: First, remove the heads and legs if they’re still attached. Then, peel off the clear shells. Once the shells are off, make a slit down the backs of the shrimp and pull the dark veins out with your fingers. When you’re finished, rinse the shrimp off with some water.Did you know? You can serve shrimp with or without the tail on. Some people think the tail adds to the final presentation of the dish, but it’s up to you. If you leave the tail on, just pull it off before you eat the shrimp.

steps.headline: Saute the shrimp in melted butter over medium heat for 3-4 minutes.
steps.description: Start by melting 2 tablespoons (28 grams) of butter in a large skillet over medium heat. Then, transfer the peeled and deveined shrimp to the pan and cook them for 3-4 minutes or until both sides of the shrimp are pink. Stir the shrimp frequently as you saute them so they cook evenly.

steps.headline: Remove the shrimp from the heat and transfer them to a plate.
steps.description: Go ahead and set the plate of shrimp aside for now while you work on the sauce.

steps.headline: Add minced garlic to the skillet and cook it over medium heat until it’s fragrant.
steps.description: Use 2 teaspoons (5 grams) of minced garlic. Stir the garlic constantly as you cook it so it doesn’t burn. It should take about 30 seconds for it to start producing an aroma. For the best flavor, use freshly-minced garlic. However, if you’re in a rush, store-bought minced garlic will work too.

steps.headline: Add wine, lemon juice, and butter and cook the sauce for 2 minutes.
steps.description: Use ⁄3 cup (79 mL) of white wine, 1 tablespoon (15 mL) of lemon juice, and 3 tablespoons (42 grams) of butter. After adding everything to the pan, continue to stir the sauce for 2 minutes or until it’s thickened. At this point, you can also season the sauce with a little salt and pepper if you'd like. You can use any kind of white wine, including chardonnay, pinot grigio, or sauvignon blanc.

steps.headline: Remove the sauce from the heat and add the sauteed shrimp.
steps.description: After you add the shrimp to the skillet, stir everything together so the shrimp is evenly coated in the sauce. To add some extra flavor and color to your dish, sprinkle 1/4 cup (6 grams) of fresh parsley over it while it’s still in the pan.

steps.headline: Serve the shrimp immediately while it’s still warm.
steps.description: You can pair your buttery garlic shrimp with some pasta or rice, or you can serve them on their own. For something light and healthy, try topping a salad with the shrimp and serving it with a warm French baguette. To store leftover shrimp, put them in an airtight container and keep it in the fridge for up to 4 days or in the freezer for up to 3 months. Once the shrimp develop a slimy texture and bad odor, they’ve gone bad and should be thrown in the trash.

steps.headline: Preheat the oven to 400 °F (204 °C) and grab a large baking sheet.
steps.description: Any kind of large baking sheet will work, but you may want to use one with raised edges so you don’t have to worry about the shrimp sliding off. Don’t worry about greasing or lining the baking sheet—the shrimp will be tossed in oil, so they shouldn’t stick.

steps.headline: Peel and devein 1 pound (0.45 kg) of uncooked shrimp.
steps.description: To peel and devein the shrimp, start by pulling off the heads and legs if they’re still on the shrimp you bought. Then, pull off the shells with your fingers and cut a slit down the back of each shrimp with a knife. Finally, pull out the dark vein in each shrimp through the slit you cut. You can leave the tail on or off depending on your preference. Leaving the tail on can make your final dish look nicer, but you’ll need to pull it off or eat around it later.

steps.headline: Combine minced garlic, olive oil, and all of the seasonings in a large bowl.
steps.description: Use 3 cloves worth of minced garlic, 2 tablespoons (30 mL) of olive oil, 1 teaspoon (2 grams) of ground cumin, 1 teaspoon (8 grams) of salt, 1/2 teaspoon (4 grams) of chili powder, 1/2 teaspoon (1 gram) of paprika, 1/4 teaspoon (0.6 grams) of black pepper, and 1/4 teaspoon (0.6) of red chili flakes. Stir everything together until a smooth paste forms.Tip: You can use more or less of each seasoning depending on how spicy you want your shrimp to be. For example, if you want your shrimp to have a strong kick to it, consider using more red chili flakes and chili powder.

steps.headline: Add the shrimp to the bowl and toss everything together.
steps.description: Make sure all of the shrimp is evenly coated with the garlic and seasoning paste. You can use a spoon to turn the shrimp over in the bowl so they’re evenly coated.

steps.headline: Spread the seasoned shrimp out in an even layer on the baking sheet.
steps.description: First, pour the shrimp out of the bowl and onto the baking sheet. Then, using your hands or a cooking utensil, spread the shrimp out so they’re arranged in a single layer. Make sure the shrimp are flat on the baking sheet and that none of them are overlapping. Spreading the shrimp out in a single layer will help them cook evenly.

steps.headline: Bake the shrimp in the oven for 8-10 minutes.
steps.description: Don’t worry about flipping or stirring the shrimp at all. You’ll know the shrimp are finished when they’re opaque. If the shrimp aren’t fully cooked after 8-10 minutes, put them back in the oven for a few extra minutes.

steps.headline: Take the shrimp out of the oven and serve them immediately.
steps.description: You can serve your baked spicy garlic shrimp on their own, or you can add them to some pasta or rice to give it a flavorful kick. The shrimp might be hot right after they come out of the oven, so you may want to give them a few minutes to cool down before digging in. If you like lime, try squeezing some lime juice over the shrimp after you take it out of the oven to give it a zesty, citrus flavor. If you have leftovers, you can store them in an airtight container in the fridge for up to 4 days or in the freezer for up to 3 months. If the shrimp develop a slimy texture or bad smell, they’ve gone bad and should be tossed out.

Combine minced garlic, olive oil, and all of the seasonings in a large bowl.
